The High Court certified under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution that the case involved a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution. Hence the present appeal. The appellant was the Ruler of the State of Baster. After the passing of the Indian Independence Act, 1947, the appellant executed an Instrument of Accession to the Dominion of India on August 14, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature of the State of Madhya Pradesh passed the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950  Madhya Pradesh Act 1 of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, which received the assent of the President of India on January 22, 1951. The preamble of the Act stated that it was one to provide for the acquisition of the rights of proprietors in estates, mahals, alienated villages and alienated lands in Madhya Pradesh and to make provisions for other matters connected therewith.

concepts.unlisted_label: Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 (Act 1 of 1951)
concepts.unlisted_description: Act for acquisition of proprietary rights in estates, mahals, alienated lands

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 3 of the Act, vesting of proprietary rights in the State Government takes place on certain conditions, mentioned in that section, being complied with.

concepts.interpretation: Vesting of proprietary rights in State on compliance with conditions

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: he Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated La

anchor.surface_text: The definition of proprietor is stated in s. 2 cl.  m  and it is in relation to- the Central Provinces, includes an inferior proprietor, a protected thekadar or other thekadar, or protected headman the merged territories, means a maufidar including an ex-Ruler of an Indian State merged with Madhya Pradesh, a Zamindar, Ilaquedar, Khorposhdar or Jagirdar within the meaning of wajib-ul-arz, or any sanad, deed or other instrument, and a gaontia or a thekadar of a village in respect of which by or under the provisions contained in the wajib-ul-arz applicable to such village the maufidar, the gaontia, or the thekadar, as the case may be, has a right to recover rent or revenue from persons holding land in such village.

concepts.interpretation: Includes ex-Ruler and maufidar with right to recover rent/revenue per wajib-ul-arz; not limited to grantee

anchor.surface_text: The definition of mahal is stated in s. 2 j  and it is mahal, in relation to merged territories, means any area other than land in possession of a raiyat which has been separately assessed to land revenue, whether such land revenue be payable or has been released, compounded for or redeemed in whole or in part.

anchor.surface_text: After referring to the definition of the word proprietor in the Act, the High Court was of the opinion that the word maufidar in s. 2 m  of the Act had not been used in any narrow or technical sense. A maufidar was not only a person to whom a grant of maufi lands had been made but was also one who held land which was exempt from the payment of rent or tax.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, accordingly, dismissed his petition under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution. Two questions in the main were urged before us  1  whether the appellant is a proprietor within the meaning of that expression in the Act and  2  whether the villages in question came within the definition of the word mahal contained in the Act.

issues.text: whether the villages in question came within the definition of the word mahal contained in the Act

anchor.surface_text: Two questions in the main were urged before us  1  whether the appellant is a proprietor within the meaning of that expression in the Act and  2  whether the villages in question came within the definition of the word mahal contained in the Act. On behalf of the appellant it had also been urged that the Act could not defeat the rights of the appellant guaranteed under Art. 3 of the Merger Agreement.

issues.text: whether the appellant is an ex-Ruler for the purposes of the Act

whether the villages in Schedules A and B had been recognised as the private property of the appellant by the Government of India as required by the second and third paragraphs of the Merger Agreement

anchor.surface_text: As the rest of the villages in Schedule A and the villages in Schedule B, upto the date of the High Court judgment, had not been recognized as the private property of the appellant by the Government of India as required by the second and third paragraphs of the Merger Agreement, the appellant could not assert his ownership over them.

arguments.claim: Maufidar in s.2(m) not narrow/technical; includes holder of land exempt from rent/tax, not only grantee

anchor.surface_text: After referring to the definition of the word proprietor in the Act, the High Court was of the opinion that the word maufidar in s. 2 m  of the Act had not been used in any narrow or technical sense. A maufidar was not only a person to whom a grant of maufi lands had been made but was also one who held land which was exempt from the payment of rent or tax.

arguments.court_reasoning: Ordinary dictionary meaning; common ground villages exempt

arguments.court_reasoning: Art. 366(22) only for Constitution; ex-Ruler ordinary meaning

arguments.claim: Ex-Ruler given ordinary dictionary meaning; appellant ceased to rule after agreements

anchor.surface_text: The expression Ruler as defined in Art. 366 22  of the Constitution applied only for interpreting the provisions of the Constitution. The expression ex-Ruler given in the Act must therefore be given the ordinary dictionary meaning. ... Accordingly the appellant must be regarded as an ex-Ruler

Petition not maintainable for other villages not recognized as private property per Merger paras 2 & 3

anchor.surface_text: As for the other villages, in Schedules A and B of the petition of the appellant under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution the High Court, in our opinion, rightly held that the petition was not maintainable as these villages had not yet been recognised by the Government of India as the private property of the appellant.

holdings.text: any dispute arising out of the Merger Agreement or the Instrument of Accession is beyond the competence of the courts to enquire into in view of the provisions of Art. 363(1) of the Constitution
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit textual provision of Art. 363(1) bars judicial interference; High Court rightly so held

holdings.text: The appellant is an ex-Ruler for the purposes of the Act as he factually ceased to rule after ceding the State via agreements
holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual cession under agreements terminated ruling status; ordinary dictionary meaning applies outside Constitution

holdings.text: Art. 366(22) definition of Ruler applies only for purposes of the Constitution and privy purse under Art. 291, not for the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 366(22) limited to constitutional interpretation; Merger Agreement factually ends rule but preserves for privy purse

holdings.text: The appellant is a proprietor under s.2(m) of the Act as an ex-Ruler of a merged State and as a maufidar
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly included in definition; qualifies independently as maufidar holding rent-free land exempt from tax

holdings.text: There is no material to establish that the appellant as maufidar had no right to recover rent or revenue per wajib-ul-arz
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence or pleading raised in lower court or certificate application; burden on appellant not discharged

holdings.text: The villages in question are mahals under s.2(j) of the Act as they have been separately assessed to land revenue
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence villages never assessed; documents confirm assessment for Bhandar villages; factual question denied by State

holdings.text: The petition is not maintainable in respect of other villages in Schedules A and B not recognised as private property of appellant by Government of India per Merger Agreement
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of recognition under paras 2 and 3 of Merger Agreement prevents assertion of ownership; High Court rightly held

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the second point arising out of the definition of Mahal, the High Court definitely found that the petitioner had given noevidence to establish that the villages in question were not assessed to land revenue. On the contrary, at least with reference to the Bhandar villages documents on the record showed that these villages had been assessed to land revenue. Since it was a question of fact whether the villages had been assessed to land revenue, which was denied on behalf of the State of Madhya Pradesh, the High Court rightly held that the contention of the appellant in this respect could not be accepted. As for the other villages, in Schedules A and B of the petition of the appellant under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution the High Court, in our opinion, rightly held that the petition was not maintainable as these villages had not yet been

outcome.relief_summary: High Court dismissal of petition under Arts. 226 and 227 upheld on all grounds; appellant's claims that he is not a proprietor and villages not mahals rejected

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the second point arising out of the definition of Mahal, the High Court definitely found that the petitioner had given noevidence to establish that the villages in question were not assessed to land revenue. On the contrary, at least with reference to the Bhandar villages documents on the record showed that these villages had been assessed to land revenue. Since it was a question of fact whether the villages had been assessed to land revenue, which was denied on behalf of the State of Madhya Pradesh, the High Court rightly held that the contention of the appellant in this respect could not be accepted. As for the other villages, in Schedules A and B of the petition of the appellant under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution the High Court, in our opinion, rightly held that the petition was not maintainable as these villages had not yet been

edges.explanation: Holding h2 appellant is ex-Ruler supports h4 appellant proprietor as ex-Ruler
Holding determines appellant is ex-Ruler under Act based on factual cessation, directly addressing the issue.
Inferred from holding.resolves_issue field
